awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: STEM Transformative Experiences Project
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI program will also generate new knowledge about how to achieve these aims.  This project at Saint Peter's University will advance the aims of the HSI Program by providing 45 high-impact, off-campus internship experiences each year to low income undergraduate students who are pursuing STEM degrees.  Low income students can face financial barriers that restrict participation in co-curricular internships, as well as cultural and academic barriers that can lower self-efficacy and self-identity as a scientist when participating in such experiences. To help students overcome these barriers, the project will place students into STEM internships and provide coordinated mentoring from a triad of mentors (a STEM faculty member, the STEM internship coordinator, and the internship supervisor).  The project will develop, implement, assess, and evaluate the three major project components: (1) partnerships with non-academic STEM institutions; (2) the triad mentor networks; and (3) professional development activities to improve mentorship.  Expected project outcomes include increased student awareness of STEM careers, increased student identity as a STEM practitioner, and contribution of the experience to students' long-term career trajectories.  The internship and triad mentoring experiences are predicted to improve student workplace performance and support sustainable partnerships between the university and non-academic STEM institutions. 

This project will implement an iterative, design-based research model to create faculty workshops, identify limitations based on the collected data, and modify workshops as needed. This design and improve process may provide a deeper understanding of how to effectively support faculty and students in mentored STEM internships, particularly for students from groups that are underrepresented in science. This research will be informed by data produced from a combination of surveys, interviews, and focus groups specifically targeting (1) barriers to success, (2) alignment between perspectives of students and mentors, and (3) academic deficiencies related to internships. During the project, both the academic and cultural results of project assessment and evaluation will be used to improve project activities. These findings have the potential to provide a design framework for effective mentoring of low-income STEM students to improve retention, to elevate their career aspirations, and to improve job placement. This project will also contribute to the knowledge base on high-impact, deliberative active learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SAINT PETER'S UNIVERSITY, A NEW JERSEY NONPROFIT CORPORATION

por.por_cntn:
Saint Peter’s University (SPU) HSI Track 1 Building Capacity project called STEM Transformative Experiences (TREX) successfully provided 212 high-impact, off-campus internship experiences to 172 STEM juniors and seniors. Financial issues and a deficient understanding of the importance of cocurricular experiences in a STEM field are significant barriers for low-income STEM students. To address these issues, TREX implemented and evaluated the following activities: (1) the development of 33 partnerships with external STEM institutions that can provide relevant STEM internship positions; (2) a unique, multifaceted mentorship model that included both student-selected network of three mentors (see below) and programmatic scaffolds iteratively improved through design-based research ; (3) a community-oriented action research model aimed at developing faculty mentorship and improve internship academic outcomes; and (4) faculty workshops on internships as high-impact components of active learning. The TREX program identified barriers to STEM students participating in internships. The program identified several important areas needing wraparound services in addition to those central goals listed above and partnered with existing organizations to leverage their capacity. This included working with local nonprofits to provide business attire and rideshare companies to provide transportation to those who would otherwise have been unable to participate in a personally-aligned internship. The STEM Internship Coordinator worked with STEM students individually to develop resumes, provided mock interviews, paired students with partnering organizations, debriefed with students and supervisors, and identified programmatic concerns that could be shared with the principal investigators. The TREX program offered STEM internships in various STEM disciplines, many of which often worked with the local community of Jersey City, NJ. The COVID-19 pandemic and required social distancing created unique challenges. Still, the TREX program was able to continue without interruption by creatively working with partner organizations to design internships that maintained social distancing and helped the community in a time of great need. To support communication among mentors and students, the TREX program developed a software application collaboratively with the interns, STEM Internship Coordinator, faculty, and workplace supervisors, who were all members of the student mentorship network.  This application facilitates reflection and communication as well as provides a centralized source of information for the analysis of students’ experiences that all mentors were able to use to guide their students actively. Workplace supervisors were also able to use the application to help them manage their workload, which was important to maintaining partnerships.  The application also prompted students to regularly reflect on their experiences.  In the STEM faculty workshops, we engaged STEM faculty as co-collaborators to contribute to a STEM Mentorship Guide that will serve as a support for mentoring underrepresented students in STEM experiential learning. The STEM Mentorship Guide also provides an understanding of how to effectively support faculty and students in mentored STEM internships, specifically for underrepresented students.  The overall performance of the TREX participants demonstrated a 96% career placement rate within six months of graduation. Additionally, the TREX participants had a four-year degree completion rate of 89%.  Together, these efforts provide a model for integrating academics and experiential learning using a student-centered mentoring network to support underrepresented students.


Last Modified: 02/01/2024
Modified by: Jeanette Wilmanski
por.por_txt_cntn:
Saint Peters University (SPU) HSI Track 1 Building Capacity project called STEM Transformative Experiences (TREX) successfully provided 212 high-impact, off-campus internship experiences to 172 STEM juniors and seniors. Financial issues and a deficient understanding of the importance of cocurricular experiences in a STEM field are significant barriers for low-income STEM students. In the STEM faculty workshops, we engaged STEM faculty as co-collaborators to contribute to a STEM Mentorship Guide that will serve as a support for mentoring underrepresented students in STEM experiential learning. Together, these efforts provide a model for integrating academics and experiential learning using a student-centered mentoring network to support underrepresented students.
